thread.title: How Mid-Market’s future will look: architecture matters
thread.title_full: How Mid-Market’s future will look: architecture matters - San Francisco Chronicle

author: John King
title: How Mid-Market’s future will look: architecture matters
text:
Photo: Atchain The current proposal for 950-974 Market St., by Handel Architects, has lost the originally planned community-oriented arts space; it will be smaller than the earlier design, with public plazas on both sides. The current proposal for 950-974 Market St., by Handel Architects,...
In the divisive prosperity of today’s San Francisco, where development is seen as either a welcome source of housing or a gentrifying scourge, it’s easy to think architecture doesn’t matter — as if it’s nothing more than the icing on a cake that should be devoured or pushed away. The current proposal for 950-974 Market St., by Handel Architects, has lost the originally planned community-oriented arts space; it will be smaller than the earlier design, with public plazas on both sides. The current proposal for 950-974 Market St., by Handel Architects,...
In the divisive prosperity of today’s San Francisco, where development is seen as either a welcome source of housing or a gentrifying scourge, it’s easy to think architecture doesn’t matter — as if it’s nothing more than the icing on a cake that should be devoured or pushed away.
